item.title: 🏆 Best Paper Award at ICHI 2024!
item.description:
🎉 Exciting News!

We are thrilled to share that our team at King’s College London (KCL) has received the Best Paper Award at this year’s International Conference on Health Informatics (ICHI 2024)! This recognition highlights our commitment to leveraging digital technology to improve the lives of stroke survivors in London.

🏥 Our Research: A Web3-Based Patient Portal

In collaboration with clinicians, social scientists, computer science experts, patients, and the public, we have developed a Web3-powered patient portal. This innovative tool enables stroke survivors to:
✅ Access their personal health records securely
✅ Manage their recovery goals effectively
✅ Improve user experience and accessibility in digital healthcare

Our work aims to empower patients in their healthcare journey, making health records more transparent, interactive, and patient-centered.

🙏 Acknowledgments

This achievement would not have been possible without the outstanding leadership and support from my colleagues at King’s:

  • Prof. Vasa Curcin
  • Dr. Iain Marshall
  • Prof. Charles Wolfe

A special thanks to the ICHI 2024 General Chairs, especially @Zhe He, for providing us with an excellent platform to present our research. Also, a huge appreciation to Davide Ferrari, PhD(c) for accepting the award on behalf of our team!

🚀 We look forward to continuing our research and driving innovation in digital health!

item.title: Published in Intensive Care Medicine – Paediatric and Neonatal: High-Frequency Vital Signs Monitoring in Critically Ill Children
item.description:
🎉 Research Published in Intensive Care Medicine – Paediatric and Neonatal

We are pleased to announce that our latest study has been published in Intensive Care Medicine – Paediatric and Neonatal. This research, titled “Distribution and Trajectory of Vital Signs from High-Frequency Continuous Monitoring in Critically Ill Children,” provides new insights into pediatric intensive care.

🔬 Key Findings

  • Investigates high-frequency vital sign monitoring in critically ill children.
  • Analyzes physiological trajectories to support early clinical interventions.
  • Offers data-driven insights to enhance real-time patient monitoring in pediatric ICUs.

This study contributes to advancing digital health solutions for pediatric critical care, aiming to support clinicians in making informed decisions for better patient outcomes.

🙌 Acknowledgments

A huge thank you to our collaborators and participating institutions for their dedication to this important research. Their support has been invaluable in driving innovation in pediatric intensive care.

📄 Read the full article here: Springer Link

🚀 Looking forward to further advancements in pediatric health informatics!
